title: My teacher made a mistake of 10 points on my test. If I tell her and she changes the grade, I will no longer have an A. Should I tell her and accept the bad grade? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m the kind of person who would be more hurt by the guilt of not telling my teacher than by the consequences of the grade. That kind of thing really eats me up. Now, I’d never had to put that into practice, that I can remember, in a situation where my grade really depended on it. Usually, my final grade would not change regardless of the change, and so I felt absolutely no qualms about owning up. And teachers have always said “Thank you for letting me know. Will it drop your grade if I change it?” I would answer no, and they would change the grade so everything was nice and honest, and everyone was happy. This wasn’t usually a big deal for me. I don’t give a crap about grades. In what would turn out to be my last week in an actual high school, I had a situation like this. I had not turned in an AP Literature assignment. It was a big assignment. I had pretty much resigned myself to the fact that this would mean a B in my favorite class. The teacher was a wonderful, extremely busy woman, who we will call Ms. Sanchez, because that was her name. She had entered an A into the gradebook instead of the expected Z. That gave me a 3.51 in the class — 0.02 points shy of a B. Well, shit. This was the one class where I would have liked an A, just to have something to back up my reputation as the English geek. (I am the English geek, but sometimes people are like “oh yeah? I don’t even like English, and I have a 4.0 in the class, so I guess all that reading isn’t helping you, haha!” And then I seethe silently, because I read instead of doing homework, because I have a horrible attention span for homework. Anyway.) But principles are principles. “Ms. Sanchez, you’ve put in an A for the Frankenstein assignment. I haven’t done the Frankenstein assignment.” “Well, you really should have, shouldn’t you?” She’s that kind of teacher. “Um, yes?” She changed it, and my grade tanked. I was now on the verge of a C. “Wow,” said Ms. Sanchez, looking at the online gradebook. “That’s not great.” And then she changed it back. I must have looked surprised, probably because I was. “Oh, stop pretending you’re surprised. You’ve basically taught more than one period of this class. I know you read the book. You taught the book to all the dumbasses who didn’t read the book. Now go away, I’m busy.” This particular teacher is both an AP English Lit teacher and the head of the Medical academy of my school. Because of this, she’s both an administrator and a teacher, which means she’s at least twice as busy as a teacher usually is. And since our class is right after lunch, she was often held up by administrators, sometimes for twenty or thirty minutes. I would lead a class discussion about Frankenstein in those twenty minutes, which I enjoyed immensely, because I’m an English nerd, and which my classmates appreciated, because they had mostly either not read or not understood the book. The ones that had read and understood it appreciated the refresher, because Ms. Sanchez’s quizzes are scary. Now, I don’t consider that teaching. That is the fun and exciting part of teaching. But it had apparently given me a free pass on a long and tedious assignment, which I hadn’t done because it was long and tedious, so I wasn’t about to complain. “Thanks. Have a good weekend.” So if I were you, I would tell her. The worst that will happen, if your teacher is particularly heartless, is that you’ll get a bad grade. But I think you’ll be pleasantly surprised.

At this time I have 19 years teaching experience and about 3 subbing. Teachers make mistakes, they appreciate knowing where they went wrong, they might give you the credit. I have two stories. First one, a programming class, I was supposed to finish 4 projects to get an A. For each project that worked, you get your grade bumped one, so pretty straightforward. My program had no errors (Pascal or Fortran) but it would not work. I took an incomplete and worked the whole next two semesters and the teacher and I could never figure out what was wrong. He offered a C and I said no, a D was all I earned. We both agreed that while I was great at using the computer, I would not make a good programmer. The next was for machine language class. We had lunch somewhere and he passed slips of paper around telling us to put down our grade and why. I put down a B, because I knew I had not learned as much as I could of. I got a B while everyone else got an A. The second semester he didn’t ask, so I got an A. Give me the right manuals and to this day I could probably make a little car go across the screen of an AppleIIe, but it would take me 5 years to do it. Just because I know how computers work, doesn’t mean I can always figure them out.
